case_vignette: A 50-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-year history of intermittent, nonproductive, chronic cough, as well as mild dyspnea with exertion. He has a 20-pack-year history of smoking and is a current smoker. His medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus, which he has controlled with diet and exercise. He also takes lisinopril. On physical examination, blood pressure is 125/76 mm Hg, pulse rate is 78/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, oxygen saturation is 98% (breathing room air), and his BMI is 25 kg/m2. There is no jugular venous distention. Heart sounds are normal, and there is no murmur. Auscultation of the lungs reveals faint, bilateral wheezing. No peripheral edema is noted. The remainder of the examination is normal.
question: Which  is most likely to confirm the diagnosis for this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Cardiovascular System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having an intermittent, nonproductive cough and mild shortness of breath when I exert myself for the past two years.
How old are you?
I am 50 years old.
Do you have any history of heart disease or high blood pressure?
I do have high blood pressure but no heart disease.
Do you have a family history of heart disease or any other cardiovascular issues?
I haven't mentioned anything about my family's medical history, so I don't have that information to share.
Have you been diagnosed with any other medical conditions and are you currently on any medications?
Yes, I have hypertension and type 2 diabetes, which I manage with diet, exercise, and I also take lisinopril.
**Final Diagnosis:** Chronic stable angina
